articles.headline: Times Ousts Jill Abramson as Executive Editor, Elevating Dean Baquet
articles.snippet: Ms. Abramson, who took over the newsroom in 2011, was abruptly dismissed and replaced by Mr. Baquet, the newspaper’s managing editor.
articles.abstract: Ms. Abramson, who took over the newsroom in 2011, was abruptly dismissed and replaced by Mr. Baquet, the newspaper’s managing editor.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times dismissed Jill Abramson as executive editor on Wednesday, replacing her with Dean Baquet, the managing editor, in an abrupt change of leadership.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66
articles.snippet: Many are trading traditional homes for lives of mobility, freedom and spontaneity.
articles.abstract: Many are trading traditional homes for lives of mobility, freedom and spontaneity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim and Jaylene Myers knew exactly what they wanted to do when they retired in 2008: Go wherever whim and chance might take them in their 45-foot recreational vehicle.

articles.headline: Organizing Your Photos, Cloud-Free
articles.snippet: LyveHome has created a nifty way to arrange your photographs without using the cloud, but the system still needs a little smoothing out.
articles.abstract: LyveHome has created a nifty way to arrange your photographs without using the cloud, but the system still needs a little smoothing out.
articles.lead_paragraph: About a week ago, I installed a small device in my home office that has been working to collect and catalog just about every photograph and video I’ve ever captured with a digital camera.

articles.headline: Tales of Escapees in Nigeria Add to Worries About Other Kidnapped Girls
articles.snippet: Some of the 53 schoolgirls who escaped Boko Haram kidnappers told of their terror, and President Goodluck Jonathan rejected the militant group’s demand for a prisoner exchange.
articles.abstract: Some of the 53 schoolgirls who escaped Boko Haram kidnappers told of their terror, and President Goodluck Jonathan rejected the militant group’s demand for a prisoner exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Among the lucky ones, there are pensive smiles but not much laughter.

articles.headline: The Age Premium: Retaining Older Workers
articles.snippet: Valuing knowledge and experience, some employers are making extra efforts to encourage longtime workers to stay.
articles.abstract: Valuing knowledge and experience, some employers are making extra efforts to encourage longtime workers to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when digital skills are prized and businesses place a premium on youth, some employers subtly seek to push out older workers. They deny them raises once awarded routinely, reduce their responsibilities or give evaluations that are cold and complain of waning productivity.

articles.headline: Fast Food Protests Spread Overseas
articles.snippet: Workers are planning strikes in 150 cities in the United States on Thursday, and they will be backed by protests in 30 countries.
articles.abstract: Workers are planning strikes in 150 cities in the United States on Thursday, and they will be backed by protests in 30 countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even though fast food workers have staged several one-day strikes in the last 18 months, the protests have not swayed McDonald’s or other major restaurant chains to significantly raise their employees’ pay.

articles.headline: One Court Ruling on Privacy in Europe, and 28 Regulators
articles.snippet: Europe’s highest court defended its citizens’ right to privacy. But it left unstated what the channels and particulars are.
articles.abstract: Europe’s highest court defended its citizens’ right to privacy. But it left unstated what the channels and particulars are.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The ruling on Tuesday by Europe’s highest court that Google can be forced to remove links from certain searches will be carried out by data privacy regulators at 28 different agencies across the European Union.

articles.headline: France’s Sale of 2 Ships to Russians Is Ill-Advised, U.S. Warns
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry said in a meeting with the French foreign minister that the delivery of the vessels would not help the political situation in eastern Europe.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said in a meeting with the French foreign minister that the delivery of the vessels would not help the political situation in eastern Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a closed-door meeting in February 2010, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urged his French counterpart not to proceed with the sale of two amphibious assault ships to Russia because it “would send the wrong message to Russia and to our allies in Central and East Europe.”

articles.headline: Soaring Earnings of Chipotle’s 2 Bosses Raise Investor Unease
articles.snippet: Chipotle’s two chief executives together earned $50 million last year. Investor unease is rising.
articles.abstract: Chipotle’s two chief executives together earned $50 million last year. Investor unease is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an era of what many perceive as outsize executive compensation, it’s not unusual for a successful public company to lavish its chief executive with a multimillion-dollar pay package. But what happens when there are two chiefs?

articles.headline: F.C.C. Backs Opening Net Neutrality Rules for Debate
articles.snippet: The Federal Communications Commission voted 3-2 to open for public debate new rules meant to guarantee an open Internet.
articles.abstract: The Federal Communications Commission voted 3-2 to open for public debate new rules meant to guarantee an open Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators appear to share one view about so-called net neutrality: It is a good thing.
